title-group.article-title: The Power of the Past: Structural Nostalgia in Elizabeth Bowen'sThe House in ParisandThe Little Girls

abstract.p: Elizabeth Bowen subjects both her characters and her readers to the dynamics of nostalgia in two of her novels.The House in ParisandThe Little Girlsare unique in Bowen'soeuvrein their use of “structural nostalgia”—a tripartite structure containing a section that takes place in the past put between two sections that take place in the present. Though this structure suggests that readers may simply engage in a nostalgic return along with the characters, Bowen uses it instead to force both her characters and her readers into a conscious examination of both the pleasures and the problems created by nostalgia.

ref.mixed-citation: Brooks has noted an analogous pattern in one of Balzac 's novels, La Peau de Chagrin , that shares the same structural chronology as Bowen's novels and in the same way “violates the usual structure of desire in the novel, which is oriented toward the end” (49). His subsequent discussion of the death drive as it affects the protagonist's unwillingness to live in the third and final section of the novel resonates to a certain extent with Bowen's portrayal of her protagonists in the present sections of her novels, but Bowen's interest (and mine) lies more in examining the effect of nostalgia than, as Brooks' does, in the “conviction […] that plot is the internal logic of the discourse of mortality” (22).

A. S. Byatt , from whose introduction to The House in Paris I take the phrase, provides the ultimate example of this tendency, as she reads the novel not only as a story about Leopold's discovery of the past and consequent development of identity, but also in reference to her past experiences with the novel and the development of her own identity as a reader and a writer.

One can only speculate that Bowen receives negative criticism because her novels initially appear more accessible than those of her contemporaries, so that when her readers encounter difficulty she is viewed as inept, while other writers who flout convention more exuberantly are viewed as brilliantly innovative.

Paul Ricoeur best describes Iser's revision of Poulet, though he does not explicitly say that he is doing so, in the following passage: “To the extent that readers subordinate their expectations to those developed by the text, they themselves become unreal to a degree comparable to the unreality of the fictive world towards which they emigrate. Reading then becomes a place, itself unreal, where reflection takes a pause. On the other hand, inasmuch as readers incorporate […] into their vision of the world the lessons of their readings […] then reading is for them something other than a place where they come to rest; it is a medium they cross through” (414).

Indeed, Kemp's argument is comparable to my own, but rather than focusing on narrative structure to make her point about Bowen's reaction to nostalgia, she examines primarily the way in which Bowen shows that objects cannot hold up to the nostalgic significance with which we imbue them and finally asserts that“The Little Girlsis a search for a new language where people and objects are not contaminated by a vocabulary of feeling”(137).

Bennett and Royle make a similar observation in their discussion ofThe House in Pariswhere they explain the phenomenon thus: “Events, thoughts, cognition in Part I of the novel […] are at once traversed and riven by what is to be read in Part II” (45). But they argue that “the tripartite division of The House in Paris [thus] participates in a specific and systematic dissolution of temporality” (42), while I argue that Bowen is not dissolving time, but consciously manipulating it so that the reader understands the force of the past. Similarly, while Bennett and Royle note in their discussion of The Little Girls that“Bowen's writing ceaselessly defers, departs from, displaces the presence of the present”(129), I agree with their analysis of the effect of Bowen's writing but not of her motive, one they again see as a postmodern deconstruction of temporality that is meant to emphasize its artificial nature rather than, as I see it, a statement on the need to reconstruct the present.
